Tiba-tiba jadi buta [METROTV]
01 Nov 2019, 07:00 by Suraya Roslan



DUA tahun dia berada dalam kegelapan untuk reda menerima ketentuan Ilahi apabila tiba-tiba mata yang dapat melihat ‘ditarik’ nikmatnya oleh Allah.
Gadis ini bukan calang-calang, dengan ketinggian luar biasa, dia dipilih mewakili Selangor dalam pasukan bola keranjan,g sekali gus menempatkan dirinya dalam Akademi Bola Keranjang Malaysia.
Lebih manis, gadis ini, Nur Azleen Jamaluddin, 35, namanya tercatat dalam Malaysia Book of Records (MBOR) sebagai wanita paling tinggi di Malaysia dengan ketinggian 194 sentimeter (6 kaki 4.5 inci).
Bagaimanapun, gadis ini perlu menerima suratan takdir apabila zaman kegemilangannya diragut sekelip mata selepas disahkan separuh buta akibat penyakit glaukoma dan kencing manis.
Pada 1993, ketika membuat pemeriksaan kesihatan untuk memasuki akademi sukan, dia disahkan menghidap Acromegaly Gigantism iaitu ketinggian luar biasa, sekali gus mengganggu kesihatannya sedikit demi sedikit.
Sejak daripada itu, kesihatan Nur Azleen mula merosot yang turut menjejaskan hormonnya sehingga perlu menjalani pembedahan membuang ketumbuhan kelenjar pituitari (kelenjar hormon) seterusnya mendatangkan penyakit kencing manis, darah tinggi, tiroid, artritis seterusnya kini glukoma.


NUR Azleen menunjukkan sijil MBOR miliknya. FOTO Faiz Anuar

Nur Azleen akui, pada mulanya sukar untuk dirinya menerima takdir Ilahi namun percaya mungkin itu hikmah buatnya menuju syurga abadi.
“Tipulah kalau saya kata tidak down, lagi-lagi jika bangun pagi saya selalu terfikir apa saya mahu buat hari ini.
“Saya cuba menyibukkan diri dan tidak mahu berfikir sangat mengenai penyakit, saya fikir setiap apa yang Allah jadikan pada saya itu bukan kebetulan, itulah perancangan Dia dan mesti ada hikmahnya,” kata anak sulung daripada tiga beradik itu.
Katanya, dia percaya walaupun sukar menerima takdir Ilahi, pelbagai hikmah datang supaya dia sentiasa mendekatkan diri kepada Tuhan sejak matanya mula kabur tiga tahun lalu.
“Saya percaya Allah, Rasulullah dan malaikat selalu ada dan mendoakan saya, itu saja semangat saya sekiranya mahu berputus asa.
“Pernah satu ketika saya macam berada di terowong gelap, saya tidak tahu arah mana mahu pergi dan saya tidak nampak cahaya serta merasakan depan, belakang, kiri dan kanan seolah-olah tembok.
“Saya tidak boleh ke mana-mana, tetapi saya kena sabar, percaya dan reda pasti ada hikmah kenapa Allah memilih saya untuk melalui semua ujian ini,” katanya.


USTAZAH Hazlina memeluk Nur Azleen ketika berkunjung ke rumahnya. FOTO Faiz Anuar

Beliau yang juga bekas penuntut jurusan Media dan Komunikasi di Universiti Teknologi Mara (UiTM) Shah Alam berkata, agak sukar untuk dirinya menerima keadaan diri apabila tangannya teraba-raba dinding rumah untuk berjalan ketika dirinya masih berada di kemuncak.
“Fokus saya sekarang adalah akhirat manakala di dunia tempat kita buat kebaikan dan pahala. Saya akui tidak mampu membantu ibu dan arwah bapa di dunia tapi di akhirat mungkin saya dapat membantu mereka,” katanya.
Akuinya, sebagai penguat semangatnya, dia akan mendengar radio dan kata-kata motivasi daripada penceramah jemputan.
“Inilah ubat untuk rohani saya, kata-kata semangat saja dapat membantu saya meneruskan hidup secara positif.
“Saya sudah tidak dapat melihat, apatah lagi menonton televisyen. Hanya dapat dengar suara di radio dan mengikuti segmen Ustazah Hazlina (Abd Razak) membuatkan saya bersemangat dan booster untuk meneruskan hidup,” katanya.
Nur Azleen turut mengakui, jika ibunya, Norhayati Tumin, 58, pergi meninggalkannya menuju dunia abadi, pastinya sukar untuk dirinya kerana ibunya saja tempatnya meluahkan perasaan dan bergantung harap.
“Kadang-kadang saya ada terfikir juga jika mak saya sudah tiada macam mana mahu meneruskan hidup, namun saya serahkan diri kepada Allah, cukup Allah jaga saya, saya tidak perlu berharap orang lain,” katanya.


NUR Azleen berjalan sekitar rumahnya. FOTO Faiz Anuar



NUR Azleen ditemani ibunya, Norhayati di Telok Menegon, Klang. FOTO Faiz Anuar

Suddenly blind [METROTV]
01 Nov 2019, 07:00 by Suraya Roslan



TWO years he was in the darkness to accept divine providence when suddenly his eyes could see his 'drawn' favor from God.
This girl is not a badass, with extraordinary height, she was chosen to represent Selangor on the basketball team, and thus placed herself in the Malaysian Basketball Academy.
More sweet, this girl, Nur Azleen Jamaluddin, 35, is listed in the Malaysia Book of Records (MBOR) as the tallest woman in Malaysia at 194 centimeters (6 feet 4.5 inches) tall.
However, this girl had to receive fate when her golden age was snatched away after being blindly diagnosed with glaucoma and diabetes.
In 1993, while undergoing a medical examination to enter a sports academy, he was diagnosed with Acromegaly Gigantism, which is an unusual height, affecting his health gradually.
Since then, Nur Azleen's health has begun to decline which also affects her hormone and has to undergo surgery to remove the pituitary gland (hormone) gland and cause diabetes, hypertension, thyroid, arthritis and now glucose.


NUR Azleen shows her MBOR certificate. PHOTO Faiz Anuar

Nur Azleen admits that at first it was difficult for her to accept the divine destiny but believed it might be wisdom for her to go to eternal heaven.
"That's when I say I'm not down, but when I get up in the morning I always wonder what I want to do today.
"I try to be selfish and not want to think too much about illness, I think whatever God has given me is not a coincidence, that is His plan and it must be wisdom," said the eldest of the three siblings.
He said he believed that although difficult to accept Divine destiny, various wisdom came so that he had always been close to God since his eyes began to fade three years ago.
"I believe that Allah, the Messenger of Allah and His angels are always there and pray for me, that's just my spirit if I want to give up.
“One time when I was in a dark tunnel, I didn't know where to go and I couldn't see the light and felt the front, back, left and right as if it were a wall.
"I can't go anywhere, but I have to be patient, confident and relieved that there is wisdom as to why God chose me to pass all these tests," he said.


USTAZAH Hazlina hugged Nur Azleen on her way home. PHOTO Faiz Anuar

He is a former student of Media and Communications at Shah Alam University of Technology (UiTM), saying it was difficult for him to accept his condition when his hand slid down the wall of the house to walk when he was still at the height.
“My focus now is on the hereafter while in the world where we do good and reward. I admit I can't help my mom and dad in the world but in the future maybe I can help them, ”he said.
Admittedly, as his motivator, he would hear the radio and the motivational words from the guest speaker.
“This is a remedy for my spirituality, just words of spirit can help me to live a positive life.
"I can't see anymore, let alone watch television. Just hearing the radio and following the Ustazah Hazlina (Abd Razak) segment made me excited and the booster to continue living, ”he said.
Nur Azleen also admits that if her mother, Norhayati Tumin, 58, left her to the eternal world, it would have been difficult for her as her mother expressed her feelings and hope.
"Sometimes I wonder if my mom has no choice but to give up my life, but I surrender to God, God is my guardian, I don't have to hope for others," he said.


NUR Azleen walks around her house. PHOTO Faiz Anuar



NUR Azleen was accompanied by her mother, Norhayati in Menegon Bay, Klang. PHOTO Faiz Anuar
